user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_register_generic_device:
```c
int metal_register_generic_device(struct metal_device *device)
{
	if (!device->name || !strlen(device->name) ||
	    device->num_regions > METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS)
		return -EINVAL;

	device->bus = &metal_generic_bus;
	metal_list_add_tail(&_metal.common.generic_device_list,
			    &device->node);
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_register_generic_device:
struct metal_device {
	const char             *name;       /**< Device name */
	struct metal_bus       *bus;        /**< Bus that contains device */
	unsigned int           num_regions; /**< Number of I/O regions in
						 device */
	struct metal_io_region regions[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS]; /**< Array of
							I/O regions in device*/
	struct metal_list      node;       /**< Node on bus' list of devices */
	int                    irq_num;    /**< Number of IRQs per device */
	void                   *irq_info;  /**< IRQ ID */
}
...
struct metal_bus metal_weak metal_generic_bus = {
	.name = "generic",
	.ops  = {
		.bus_close = NULL,
		.dev_open  = metal_generic_dev_open,
		.dev_close = NULL,
		.dev_irq_ack = NULL,
		.dev_dma_map = metal_generic_dev_dma_map,
		.dev_dma_unmap = metal_generic_dev_dma_unmap,
	},
}
...
struct metal_list {
	struct metal_list *next, *prev;
}
...
extern struct metal_state _metal
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: struct metal_bus       *bus;        /**< Bus that contains device */
explanation:
Fragments not reported as suspicious and why:
- device->name is declared as const char *name; it is already const-qualified and only read (strlen), so Rule 8.13 is satisfied for that pointer.
- The function parameter struct metal_device *device and the struct metal_device fields that represent mutable state (regions array, node, irq_num, irq_info) are intentionally mutable: the function modifies device->bus and updates the device list (metal_list_add_tail) which requires modifying node/linked-list pointers. Making these pointers/objects const would prevent necessary mutations, so they are not flagged.
- The linked-list pointers (struct metal_list *next, *prev) must remain mutable because list operations update them; they are therefore not candidates for const-qualification.
- Other symbols referenced (e.g. extern struct metal_state _metal) represent mutable global state used for device registration and are not flagged because they are intended to be modified.
- Function pointer entries inside metal_generic_bus.ops are pointers to functions (not pointers to data that could be const-qualified in the sense of Rule 8.13) and are used as callbacks; they are not considered violations of this rule in this context.

The flagged fragments focus on the bus pointer and the global bus instance because assigning &metal_generic_bus to a non-const struct metal_bus * suggests the bus object or the device->bus member might be better qualified with const to comply with MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 if the bus contents are immutable.
